title: Military Convoy Explosion
instructions:
It's around noon on a hot day in April.  You are in one of the middle trucks on a convoy in the middle of the desert.
You tighten the muscles in your face and forehead. Your eyes, scan the area, looking for any signs of danger. You hear an explosion from up the road.
Your heart beats faster. You hear the loud blast, then a ringing in your ears. You are breathing faster. You see the lead truck pull sideways and stop.
You tense the muscles in your jaws and back. You see your medic run up the road to help out. You think: “Oh my God, they're all dead”. You feel hot all over.
You squint your eyes and look for your friend in the turret. But all you see is smoke and dust. Both your commanders are yelling for you to keep your head up.
Now you have to cover the field on both sides. You feel jittery and shaky all over. Your whole body is shaking. We're supposed to leave the area under all
this gunfire. Your stomach is in a knot. Your whole body is tense. Everyone's confused and there's no leadership. There's a sinking feeling in your chest.
You feel trapped. Suddenly, you realize you haven't been paying attention to your sector. You look around frantically for the enemy. Your heart is pounding.
Your hands clench the weapon tightly. You accidentally pulled the trigger and send out a couple of rounds. Sweat is pouring off your forehead.
You feel choked up. You feel helpless and alone. You think about your wife and kids. You breathe in smoke from the explosive.
You feel empty, drained, and hollow. Tears come to your eyes.

title: Coastal Storm Flooding
instructions:
It's late afternoon on a humid day in August. You're in a small wooden house near the coast. The wind outside is howling, stronger than you've ever heard before.
Your fingers dig into the sides of the couch, clenching tight. The windows shake violently, giving you glimpses of the furious storm outside. You hear a deafening crash — a tree has fallen nearby.
Your heart races, adrenaline surging through you. The floor beneath you vibrates, and a torrential rain pours outside, drumming hard on the roof. You try to breathe deeply, but your chest feels tight.
You think: \"This is it, the house will be swept away\". Water starts seeping in, first a trickle, then a flood, cold against your feet. The power's out, and with every gust of wind, the structure creaks and groans.
You move to the center of the room, away from the windows, but feel so exposed. The pit in your stomach grows. The walls of the house shudder.
The sound is deafening. You close your eyes and think of your family, hoping they're safe. Suddenly, there's a loud crash, and water rushes in faster. 
It's up to your ankles now, cold and relentless. You scramble onto the couch, trying to keep your balance. There's a sinking feeling in your chest. 
You're trapped, and there's no way out. All around you, the storm rages on, indifferent to your fear. You feel alone, lost in its fury, wondering if dawn will ever come.

title: Apartment Intruder
instructions:
You're in your downtown apartment, the familiar hum of the city below. Suddenly, there's a loud knock at the door. 
Your muscles tighten, a wave of unease surging through you. You weren't expecting anyone. Another knock, more forceful this time. 
You inch closer, cautiously peeping through the peephole. There's a shadowy figure, unfamiliar and intimidating. 
Your heart races as you back away from the door, but the persistent knocking continues, now accompanied by a muffled voice demanding entry. 
You can feel the weight of dread in your chest. Thoughts race, \"Why are they here? What do they want?\" You grab your phone, contemplating calling for help, but your fingers tremble, making it hard to dial.
The sound of splintering wood sends a shock through your body. They're trying to force their way in. You think of hiding in the bathroom, or maybe the bedroom, but fear paralysis grips you. 
Suddenly, the door gives way with a loud crash. Adrenaline courses through you. The intruder's voice is sharp, cold, and demanding. You feel exposed, vulnerable. 
Every sound magnifies — the creaking floor, your rapid breath, their menacing steps. The distance between you seems to close rapidly. You're cornered.
Thoughts of loved ones flash before your eyes. Memories, dreams, things unsaid. You feel trapped, the walls closing in. The intruder's shadow looms larger, and with it, the palpable threat of violence. 
Powerlessness engulfs you. In the thick of danger, you wonder if anyone will hear, if help will come.

title: Highway Collision
instructions:
It's a crisp evening, and the highway stretches ahead, illuminated only by your car's headlights and the sparse street lamps. The radio plays a soft tune, and you're lost in thought, driving 
at a steady pace. Suddenly, out of the periphery of your vision, you spot a pair of headlights swerving erratically. Before you can even process the situation, they're coming straight for you. Time seems
to slow as you grip the steering wheel tighter, your heart hammering against your chest. Panic courses through you, and instinctively you try to swerve away. The deafening sound of metal crunching 
against metal fills your ears as the two vehicles collide. The force of the impact throws you against your seatbelt, knocking the wind out of you. Your vision blurs from the sudden jolt, and 
shards from the shattered windshield fly everywhere. The screech of tires, the blaring of horns, and the alarm of your own car create a cacophony of chaos. As the initial shock begins to 
fade, you try to move, to check yourself for injuries, but pain shoots through you. The other vehicle, equally mangled, is just a few meters away. Thoughts race, \"Was it my fault?\" 
You fumble for your phone, hands trembling, to call for help. Every sound is magnified - distant sirens, the low murmur of other drivers stopping to assist, your own ragged breathing.
Fear and helplessness wash over you. Memories of loved ones and past journeys flash through your mind. Amid the shattered glass and twisted metal, you wonder if you'll ever feel comfortable behind the wheel again.

title: Desert Ambush
instructions:
In the merciless grip of the midday sun, the desert becomes a vast, glaring oven. Each grain of sand below seems to pulse with latent menace. Your truck, sandwiched in the heart of a convoy,
feels like a metal trap. Every pore on your face tightens, every nerve strung to breaking point. You're hyper-aware, the weight of potential danger causing the very air to thicken around you. 
Without warning, a deafening explosion ruptures the silence, its violent shockwave sending a visceral jolt down your spine. Your heart doesn't just race; it gallops, threatening to leap out 
of your chest. The once-organized procession is now a scene of pandemonium, dominated by a monstrous plume of smoke where the lead truck once was. An icy dread laces your veins with the 
horrifying realization: \"They've been obliterated.\" Everywhere you turn, you're met with a blinding, choking haze. A cacophony of shouts and orders, desperate and filled with panic,
assaults your ears. But they sound distant, as if underwater, drowned out by the screaming alarm in your mind. Every fiber of your being feels electrified, vibrating with a frenzied energy.
Commands echo around you, yet they seem abstract, distant. Your gut churns, twisting in on itself, each second stretching into an agonizing eternity. Amid the turmoil, a paralyzing thought
hits: you've lost track of your position, your duty. Your mind races, thoughts scattering like leaves in a storm. Hands slick with sweat clutch your weapon so hard it's painful. 
Its cold metal feels volatile, ready to explode. The trigger yields beneath your grip, shots firing haphazardly. With every deafening report, the vision of home, of family, 
becomes more distant, more unreachable. The sharp, acrid stench of explosives fills your nostrils, a constant reminder of the looming threat. Waves of nausea, dread, and 
raw vulnerability crash over you, pulling you deeper into a vortex of overwhelming terror.

title: Military Convoy Explosion
instructions:
It is 1200 hours, and the April sun is a physical weight pressing down on the desert floor. You are positioned in the middle of the convoy, encased in a vibrating shell of metal that has become a convection oven. The air inside the truck is thick, smelling of diesel, stale sweat, and hot iron. Every time you inhale, the heat stings your lungs. Under your Kevlar helmet, sweat collects in heavy droplets, tracing slow, itching paths down your neck. You don’t wipe it away; your muscles are locked in a grimace of hyper-vigilance.
 You scan the horizon until the shimmering heat waves make the sand look like water. To the untrained eye, its just rocks and dust. To you, every silhouette is a potential trigger, every shadow a hidden threat.
 The world ends in a heartbeat.
 A blinding flash erupts at the head of the line—a white-hot sun born on the asphalt. A micro-second later, the shockwave punches you in the chest, stealing your breath. Your ears are instantly filled with an agonizing whine that drowns out the roar of the engines. You watch as the lead truck is hoisted into the air by a geyser of black smoke and orange flame. It slams back down, crumpled and unrecognizable. 
 Your heart isn't just beating; it’s a frantic animal trying to claw its way out of your ribs. Through the haze, you see the platoon medic sprinting toward the carnage without a moment’s hesitation. He vanishes into the billowing soot. 'They’re gone,'' a voice whispers in the back of your mind. 'They’re all dead.' 
 The chaos is a sensory overload. Your commanders are screaming orders, their mouths moving in jagged shapes, but the ringing in your ears turns their voices into distant, underwater echoes. You search for your friend in the turret of the vehicle ahead, but there is only a swirling wall of gray debris.
 You force your eyes back to your sector. Your hands are trembling so violently they rattle against the frame of your weapon. Then, the first 'pop-pop' of distant small-arms fire cuts through the ringing. In the terror, your focus slips. For three seconds, you stare blankly at a patch of sand, paralyzed. When you realize your lapse, panic surges. You jerk your gaze back, fingers clenching the grip of your rifle with white-knuckled intensity.
 Crack.
 Your finger, slick with sweat, slips. The weapon fires. The recoil jars your shoulder, a sharp reminder of your own frailty. The smell of cordite mixes with the acrid smoke of the burning wreckage. Your throat burns. In this vast wasteland, you have never felt more alone. The faces of your wife and children flicker across your vision—a quiet kitchen, the smell of rain—things that feel like they belong to a different soul. Your chest feels hollowed out. Tears blur the horizon into a smear of brown and red as you struggle to find the strength to stay in the fight.

title: Coastal Storm Flooding
instructions:
It is late afternoon in August, and the humidity has curdled into a nightmare. You are inside a small wooden house near the coast, a structure that suddenly feels as fragile as a birdcage. Outside, the wind isn't just blowing; it is howling with a predatory hunger, a sound more primal and terrifying than anything you’ve ever heard. 
Your fingers dig into the fabric of the couch, knuckles white and locking into place. Every few seconds, the windows shudder in their frames, offering jagged glimpses of a world turned gray and violent. Then comes a deafening, splintering crash—a massive oak has surrendered to the gale nearby, shaking the foundation beneath your feet. 
 The ocean is coming for you. 
Adrenaline surges, hot and frantic, as the floor begins to vibrate. Torrential rain drums against the roof with the rhythm of a thousand hammers. Your chest tightens, making every breath feel thin and hard-won. A dark thought takes root: 'This is it. The house is going to be swept away.' 
Then, you see it. A thin, dark ribbon of water snaking across the floorboards. What begins as a trickle quickly swells into a cold, relentless flood that swirls around your ankles. The power flickers and dies, plunging the room into a murky, bruised twilight. With every fresh gust of wind, the wooden beams groan and shriek under the pressure. 
You scramble toward the center of the room, desperate to stay away from the glass, but the space feels horribly exposed. The house shudders again—a sickening, structural lurch. Another loud crash echoes through the salt-thick air, and the water rushes in faster, rising with terrifying speed. 
You hike yourself up onto the cushions of the couch, trying to keep your balance as the water turns the living room into a dark pool. A heavy, sinking feeling settles in your chest. You are trapped in a box of splintering wood, and there is nowhere left to climb. 
Outside, the storm rages on, entirely indifferent to the frantic pounding of your heart. In the darkness, you close your eyes and pray for your family, wondering if they are shivering in the dark just like you. You feel utterly small, lost in the fury of the elements, staring toward a window you can no longer see and wondering if the sun will ever rise again

title: Apartment Intruder
instructions:
You’re in your downtown apartment, the familiar hum of the city—sirens, tires on wet pavement, distant chatter—vibrating against the glass. It’s a sound that usually brings comfort, a reminder that you aren't alone in the urban sprawl. That comfort vanishes with a sudden, heavy knock at the door that rattles the frame. 
 Your muscles lock instantly, a wave of cold unease surging through your limbs. You weren't expecting anyone, especially not at this hour. The silence that follows is heavy and suffocating, broken only by a second knock, more forceful and rhythmic than the first. You inch toward the entryway, your breath hitching, and squint through the peephole. A shadowy figure stands in the dim hallway, distorted by the lens, unfamiliar and imposing. 
Your heart races as you back away, but the knocking persists, now accompanied by a muffled, low voice demanding entry with a chilling sense of authority. A weight of dread settles in your chest, thick and immovable. Why are they here? What do they want? You reach for your phone on the counter, but your fingers tremble so violently the screen is a frantic blur. 
The sound of splintering wood sends a physical shock through your spine. They aren’t waiting anymore; they’re forcing their way in. You think of the bathroom, the bedroom, or the fire escape, but a sickening paralysis grips your legs, rooting you to the spot. Then, the door gives way with a violent crash, the wood moaning as it yields to the intruder's weight. 
Adrenaline courses through you, hot and sharp. The intruder’s voice is a jagged blade—cold, demanding, and terrifyingly close. You feel exposed, stripped of the safety you spent years building within these four walls. Every sound is magnified: the groan of the floorboards, your own frantic, shallow gasps, and the heavy, deliberate steps of someone who knows you are cornered. 
The distance between you closes in heartbeats. Memories of loved ones flash before your eyes—unspoken words, holiday dinners, and half-finished dreams flickering like a dying lightbulb. You are trapped, the very walls of your sanctuary closing in to crush you. The intruder’s shadow looms across the carpet, a dark omen of the violence to come. A sense of total powerlessness engulfs you, and as the shadow stretches toward you, you wonder if your screams will even carry past the heavy, soundproof glass of the city window.

title: Highway Collision
instructions:
It is a crisp, cool evening, and the highway stretches ahead like a ribbon of long-faded ink, illuminated only by the steady, clinical glow of your headlights and the occasional flicker of a passing street lamp. The radio plays a soft, melancholic tune—a melody that feels strangely prophetic in the stillness of the cabin. You are lost in the quiet trance of the road, your mind drifting through the small details of your day, driving at a comfortable, steady pace toward the sanctuary of home.
Suddenly, the peaceful atmosphere is shattered by a flash of movement. Out of the periphery of your vision, a pair of headlights appears, swerving erratically across the grassy median. Before your brain can even categorize the threat, they are angled directly at your driver-side door—two blinding, white-hot eyes charging through the darkness. Time seems to stretch and warp, turning seconds into an agonizing crawl. You grip the steering wheel until your knuckles turn white, your heart hammering against your ribs like a trapped bird. Panic courses through your veins, cold and electric, and you instinctively wrench the wheel to the side in a desperate, last-second bid for survival. 
The world ends in a scream of tortured metal. 
The sound of the collision is absolute—a bone-deep, visceral crunch that fills your skull as the two vehicles tear into one another. The sheer force of the impact throws you violently against your seatbelt, the fabric biting into your shoulder and chest with enough force to bruise, knocking the breath from your lungs in a single, agonizing gasp. Your vision blurs into a kaleidoscope of gray and red from the sudden, violent jolt, and the windshield disintegrates into a million glittering diamonds, sending a hail of glass shards flying through the cabin like lethal snow. 
The aftermath is a cacophony of absolute chaos—the screech of shredded tires on pavement, the frantic, unending blaring of a stuck horn, and the shrill, rhythmic alarm of your own car signaling its distress. As the initial shock begins to recede, replaced by a dull, throbbing heat, you try to shift your weight. You want to check your limbs, to see if you are still whole, but a jagged line of lightning-bolt pain shoots through your side, pinning you against the seat. 
Every sound is now terrifyingly magnified—the distant, rising wail of sirens, the low murmur of other drivers stopping to help, and the heavy, liquid sound of your own ragged breath. A wave of profound helplessness washes over you. In the dim light of the dashboard, memories of your family and flashes of past journeys flicker through your mind like a film strip breaking apart. Surrounded by the scent of burnt rubber and the cold night air rushing through the broken glass, you wonder if you will ever feel the same sense of peace behind the wheel again.

The sharp, acrid stench of high explosives fills your nostrils, a constant, burning reminder of the looming threat. Waves of nausea, raw vulnerability, and soul-crushing dread crash over you, pulling you deeper into a vortex of overwhelming terror where the only reality is the heat and the smoke.

Thoughts of loved ones flash before your eyes. Memories, dreams, things unsaid. You feel trapped, the walls closing in. The intruder's shadow looms larger, and with it, the palpable threat of violence. 
Powerlessness engulfs you. In the thick of danger, you wonder if anyone will hear, if help will come.

title: Highway Collision
instructions:
It's a crisp evening, and the highway stretches ahead, illuminated only by your car's headlights and the sparse street lamps. The radio plays a soft tune, and you're lost in thought, driving 
at a steady pace. Suddenly, out of the periphery of your vision, you spot a pair of headlights swerving erratically. Before you can even process the situation, they're coming straight for you. Time seems
to slow as you grip the steering wheel tighter, your heart hammering against your chest. Panic courses through you, and instinctively you try to swerve away. The deafening sound of metal crunching 
against metal fills your ears as the two vehicles collide. The force of the impact throws you against your seatbelt, knocking the wind out of you. Your vision blurs from the sudden jolt, and 
shards from the shattered windshield fly everywhere. The screech of tires, the blaring of horns, and the alarm of your own car create a cacophony of chaos. As the initial shock begins to 
fade, you try to move, to check yourself for injuries, but pain shoots through you. The other vehicle, equally mangled, is just a few meters away. Thoughts race, \"Was it my fault?\" 
You fumble for your phone, hands trembling, to call for help. Every sound is magnified - distant sirens, the low murmur of other drivers stopping to assist, your own ragged breathing.
Fear and helplessness wash over you. Memories of loved ones and past journeys flash through your mind. Amid the shattered glass and twisted metal, you wonder if you'll ever feel comfortable behind the wheel again.

title: Desert Ambush
instructions:
In the merciless grip of the midday sun, the desert becomes a vast, glaring oven. Each grain of sand below seems to pulse with latent menace. Your truck, sandwiched in the heart of a convoy,
feels like a metal trap. Every pore on your face tightens, every nerve strung to breaking point. You're hyper-aware, the weight of potential danger causing the very air to thicken around you. 
Without warning, a deafening explosion ruptures the silence, its violent shockwave sending a visceral jolt down your spine. Your heart doesn't just race; it gallops, threatening to leap out 
of your chest. The once-organized procession is now a scene of pandemonium, dominated by a monstrous plume of smoke where the lead truck once was. An icy dread laces your veins with the 
horrifying realization: \"They've been obliterated.\" Everywhere you turn, you're met with a blinding, choking haze. A cacophony of shouts and orders, desperate and filled with panic,
assaults your ears. But they sound distant, as if underwater, drowned out by the screaming alarm in your mind. Every fiber of your being feels electrified, vibrating with a frenzied energy.
Commands echo around you, yet they seem abstract, distant. Your gut churns, twisting in on itself, each second stretching into an agonizing eternity. Amid the turmoil, a paralyzing thought
hits: you've lost track of your position, your duty. Your mind races, thoughts scattering like leaves in a storm. Hands slick with sweat clutch your weapon so hard it's painful. 
Its cold metal feels volatile, ready to explode. The trigger yields beneath your grip, shots firing haphazardly. With every deafening report, the vision of home, of family, 
becomes more distant, more unreachable. The sharp, acrid stench of explosives fills your nostrils, a constant reminder of the looming threat. Waves of nausea, dread, and 
raw vulnerability crash over you, pulling you deeper into a vortex of overwhelming terror.
